abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for China power transmission
            project were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was low or negligible, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the borrower performance
            was satisfactory. Lessons learned from the project:
            Conducting extensive studies to ensure sound investment
            decisions is very important for developing cost-effective
            transmission systems. At the inception of the project, the
            Bank indicated that the system required more investments
            than envisaged under the project. The 500 kV river crossing
            suspension tower bid package was technically complex in
            nature and should have received greater attention during the
            review and evaluation of the qualification of supplier and
            its subcontractor. Having recognized the special nature of
            the river crossing towers in the PAD, the Bank should have
            insisted on prequalification of the prospective bidders
            prior to the issuance of the bidding documents to the
            qualified bidders. Qualification requirements should be
            specified better and particular attention should be paid to
            coordinating between commercial and technical aspects in
            similar projects. The project confirmed the need to avoid
            rigid and Bank mandated reform programs. It showed that
            flexibility is paramount to adapt the agreed program to
            institutional changes and revised reform objectives in the country.
